Householders are protected from prosecution as long as they act "honestly and instinctively" in the heat of the moment. Victims do not have to wait to be attacked if they are in their home and fear for themselves or others. Spain's Christmas lottery, known as "El Gordo" or "the fat one", is a national event. Unlike other lotteries, players do not choose numbers. They buy a ticket with a 5-digit number on and anyone who has that ticket when the the numbers are called - or, more accurately,sung out by schoolchildrenat a televised event in Madrid - wins a share of the prize. Because of the nature of the system, tickets in a series are often sold by the same vendor, meaning the winners usually come from the same towns. The draw is always held just before Christmas to offer people some festive cheer.

In two famous and famously lengthy experiments, scientists wait for the pitch to drip from a funnel. It happens about once a decade because pitch, though solid, is actually a very viscous liquid. These experiments, set up to demonstrate the fluidity and high viscosity of pitch, have captured the curiosity of both the scientific community and the public alike. The first, known as the Pitch Drop Experiment, was initiated by Professor Thomas Parnell at the University of Queensland in 1927. Remarkably, it took a decade for the first drop to fall and since then only nine drops have fallen. Similarly, Trinity College Dublin’s pitch drop experiment, which was started in 1944, has seen even fewer drops fall. These experiments, possibly the longest in history, not only show the peculiar properties of pitch but also the broader concept of patience and persistence in scientific research. They remind us of the slow pace at which some scientific phenomena occur and the dedication required to observe them.
